botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Patio roses are small bushy shrubs with clusters of single to double, slightly fragrant flowers about 3cm across, over a long period in summer and autumn

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in full sun and moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil. For best flowering apply a balanced fertiliser and mulch in late winter or early spring and a balanced fertiliser again in early summer. Ideal for cut flowers and can be grown in a container. See rose cultivation for further advice.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by hardwood cuttings in autumn or by chip budding in summer
how_to_grow.pests: Aphids, leafhoppers, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose sawfly and rose leaf-rolling sawfly may be a problem. Deer and rabbits can cause damage
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by black spot, rose rust, powdery mildews, and a downy mildew
